Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement for citizenship
Legal_Issue: Whether the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act means physical presence in Canada
Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present for only 689 days out of the required 1,095 days due to work outside Canada
Court_Ruling: Federal Court affirmed that residency means physical presence in Canada
Defendant_Behavior: Extended absence from Canada for employment purposes
Grounds_for_Claim: Residency requirement not met due to insufficient physical presence
Legal_Standard: Interpretation of 'residence' as physical presence under the Citizenship Act
Assessment_Factor: Number of days physically present in Canada within four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Citizenship Court to Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Record of entry and exit dates, travel history, employment records abroad
Application_Basis: Accumulation of at least 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years prior to application
Evidence_Assessed: Documentation of time spent outside Canada for work
Governing_Rule: Residency under s. 5(1)(c) requires physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of required physical presence
Cause_Description: Applicant's failure to meet the physical presence requirement due to extensive travel abroad for work
Evidence_Handling: Court reviewed official records of border crossings and applicant’s explanations
Evidence_Assessment: Travel records accepted as accurate; no dispute over factual basis
Decision_Rationale: The term 'residence' in the statutory context means physical presence, and absences for work do not count toward the requirement
